Good Afternoon, Goodwater Families! We wanted to let you know about this program if you do not already. Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is a one-time food benefit for families who lost access to their free or reduced-price meals due to school closures. Eligible P-EBT families should have received information via email from us today. Please check your spam/junk mail if you did not.

The P-EBT application will open the first week of June.

P-EBT food benefits are for children who received SNAP food benefits for March 2020 and children who are certified for free or reduced-price school meals during the 2019-20 Texas school year. For more information, visit: www.hhs.texas.gov/PEBT

If any of our Goodwater families have questions, please email schoolmeals@goodwatermontessori.org. Thank you!

Dr. Bruce Tabor Officially Named Goodwater Montessori Superintendent/CEO

A Note From Dr. Bruce Tabor:

On Tuesday evening, the Goodwater Board of Directors approved me for the position of Head of School. The Board also approved modifying the title to Superintendent/CEO to fall more in line with other public charter schools in Texas.

I am extremely happy to be working with all of you as the Superintendent/CEO on a permanent basis. I am excited and ready to serve our students as we move forward into the third year of operation.

Goodwater Montessori Charter School is poised to become a leader in Texas for public Montessori schools as we all work together towards the goals that align to our Mission, Vision, and Values.

Thank you to the Board for giving me the opportunity and to all of the staff and families for the work you have done this year and the sacrifices that you have made for the students of Goodwater. Without you and your commitment, there would be no school.

Sincerely,
Dr. Bruce Tabor
Superintendent/CEO

We are excited to see these students learn and grow in the way that the Montessori model allows for these developing minds.

We want to send a huge thank you to the W.D. Kelley Foundation in Georgetown for the $25,000 grant awarded to Goodwater Montessori School this week. This grant will go towards our General Operating funds for the coming school year.

Because charter schools receive less funding per pupil than traditional public schools, we must rely on fundraising to cover that gap. Support from outside organizations and individuals is crucial to our mission.

Thank you to the W.D. Kelley Foundation for your support as we bring the opportunity of a Montessori education to all of the families in Williamson County, especially those who otherwise may not be able to afford it.

Aaaaand that's a wrap! Goodwater Montessori School completed its inaugural school year last Friday. School is out for summer!

The staff is still hard at work over the next few months. We are getting ready for Year 2 of Goodwater Montessori School by reflecting on all of the lessons and friendships and accomplishments of Year 1 and setting goals and creating systems and plans and structures that will serve staff and students next year (which starts in 2 months!)

Thank you to everyone - our families, the greater community and all of our loved ones for ALL of the support and encouragement. We are so excited to see and hear how the Montessori Model has enriched the lives of our students and families already. What an amazing year it has been!

Please note that the draft calendar released in February had Spring Break during the third week of March like many area districts. The new approved calendar has Spring Break the second week of March. This is consistent with the Spring Break dates of Georgetown ISD, and since about 60% of our students live in GISD, Goodwater changed the calendar accordingly.

Also note that Goodwater has shortened the school day by 30 minutes. School Hours will be 8:00 AM - 3:15 PM - daily. Goodwater will no longer have Early Release Wednesdays.

The first day of school for students will be Tuesday, August 14th.

This week we are very happy to welcome Goodwater's new Dean of Student Affairs, Montique Chance. Ms. Chance graduated from Troy State University with a Master's degree in Counseling and Psychology and she is a licensed professional counselor intern. She has also worked as a Guidance Counselor and paraprofessional in the world of education.

As Dean of Student Affairs, she will be developing our after school program, building out our library, and organizing the Parent Organization and volunteer program. She will also be working on student services related duties in the school and cultivating relationships in the greater Williamson County area.

We are thrilled to have her on campus with us! Please feel free to email her with any ideas, questions, or concerns you may have. Her contact information is on the website.

We also want to let you know that we are working on scheduling parent information nights that will serve to inform and involve parents in your student's Montessori education. We are excited about what we have planned so stay tuned for those dates and times!

Randie Piscitello
April 6, 2017 at 8:13 AM ·

Anna is demonstrating our #SeedsofChange plant of the day, the delightful and often overlooked gourd! Gourds are a perfect plant to grow on Goodwater's eleven acres. They grow easily in our hot weather (and most need our extra long frost free days to grow to maturity), are generally pest free, and come in a variety of shapes and sizes. The gourds are cured by allowing to dry outside, and they can be used for a variety of instruments, toys, and tools. I plan on growing these aptly named caveman club gourds, which make perfect maracas once the seeds dry inside. Other varieties include spinning top, swan, apple, dipper, bowl and bottle. Gourds can be tied into history, garden and art, making them a perfect plant for a Texas school garden. Thank you again for your daily votes, link is in the comments!

March 12, 2017 at 5:58 PM ·

Seemi - Trillium Montessori is with Caitlin Zirkelbach and 4 others.
March 8, 2017 at 11:17 AM ·

Maria has a lot to teach us about standing strong and speaking up during turbulent times. She defied societal norms to become one of the first female physicians in Italy and was a fierce and vocal advocate for women's rights. In 1896 she represented Italy at the International Women’s Congress in Berlin where she delivered an address on the rights of working women, including equal pay for equal work. She was later exiled from Italy for refusing to cooperate with Mussolini's government. Maria is known for her innovations in education and was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize more than once. Her life is an example of how teaching peace and being a woman do not mean being quiet. Her work and her convictions continue to inspire millions of people today.
#proudmontessorian
#internationalwomensday

"Not only does the research continue to increase about the efficacy of Montessori methodology, if you speak to people who have had the opportunity to attend Montessori many of them think about the world differently. Alumni and present supporters as well as many who continue to work in some capacity in Montessori education long for the day that more students have access to a Montessori education-that the tipping point is reached and the global impact of a Montessori education starts to steer society in a different direction. This will be my prayer tonight and my work tomorrow as I read the news of the day and hope for a different trajectory than the one that we seem to be faced with today."

post_text: Happy 110th Anniversary, Montessori! Goodwater congratulates all the wonderful Montessorians who uphold this pedagogy around the world.
shared_text:
Monica Schmidt shared a link to the group: Why Montessori?
January 6, 2017 at 3:24 PM ·

110 years ago today:

Dr. Maria Montessori opened the first Casa dei Bambini (Children's House) on 6 January 1907 in San Lorenzo, Rome. Through her observations and work with these children she discovered their astonishing, almost effortless ability to learn. Thus began a century of great work uncovering the true nature of childhood.

"Times have changed, and science has made great progress, and so has our work; but our principles have only been confirmed, and along with them our conviction that mankind can hope for a solution to its problems, among which the most urgent are those of peace and unity, only by turning its attention and energies to the discovery of the child and to the development of the great potentialities of the human personality in the course of its formation." Dr. Montessori from the forward to "The Discovery of the Child", Poona 1948

Photo taken on the day of the opening of the Casa dei Bambini, 6 January 1907,
Via dei Marsi, 58, San Lorenzo, Rome, Italy.

post_text: Today's Goodwater Question of the Day: Do Montessori teachers give grades? Grades, like other external rewards, have little lasting effect on a child’s efforts or achievements. The Montessori approach nurtures the motivation that comes from within, kindling the child’s natural desire to learn. A self-motivated learner also learns to be self-sufficient, without needing reinforcement from outside. In the classroom, of course, the teacher is always available to provide students with guidance and support. Although most Montessori teachers don’t assign grades, they closely observe each student’s progress and readiness to advance to higher-level lessons. Goodwater will hold family conferences twice per year so parents may see their child’s work and hear the teacher’s assessment of his or her progress. Parents may also schedule a conference any time.
